Message.Title: Is the Surface RT really expensive......
Message.Msg: Surface RT has a free cover until the end of month. You also get Microsoft Office for free. So 100. + 249 = 349. So you are actually buying a Surface for about $50 beanos. The Surface RT does not let you install your own programs. You have to buy the pro for that. However, there are so many great apps, I think some of the old software will not be missed. Foursquare is in the Windows The Surface machines are drop dead gorgeous electronics. You cannot use it on your lap. It has to be put on a laptop stand or table. I have tested all of the Windows machines. If you want a touch pad that the screen does not flop around when you touch it there are two. One is the Acer Aspire I5 & I7. Those have a touch pad that is subject to your palm accidently hitting it though. The other was the Sony an that was a lot more. There are many, however I was testing for the no movement when you are touching the screen. The Surface will flop when you touch the screen because it is so light. However, the fel and accuracy of everything made the Surface actually work better. I would say the Surface just works better in everything except the floppiness of the screen due to weight and you cannot really use the laptop in your lap. You can use it as a tablet in your lap. There are a number of reasons it may perform better than other Windows Machines. If you do not use your own programs except Office than the current deal on the Surface RT is a steal.

Message.Title: Microsoft Blunders Again with Mobile Office
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "With Microsoft's (NASDAQ: MSFT) Windows 8 flop and the firm's restriction on gamers in its upcoming Xbox One release, it looked as if the company couldn't get more bad press. But then along came the new Microsoft Office Mobile for the iPhone. "If the company continues down its current path, it could become as obsolete as International Business Machines was in the 1990s. In the company's latest flub, Microsoft's Office Mobile doesn't follow basic file compatibility, said CloudOn's chief executive Milind Gadekar. It should be noted, however, that CloudOn is the rival to Microsoft's Office Mobile, so there is some bias in his opinion. Gadekar did admit, however, that the software is superior to CloudOn in its offline capabilities. "What the bad press means to Microsoft "Microsoft continues to shoot itself in the foot at a time when the company is trying to re-brand itself. The company has also faced criticism for the limitations it has put on users of the November release of the Xbox One. Industry executives say mobile gamers today are spoiled for choice as the industry has exploded. In 2007, when Apple Inc launched the iPhone, there were but a handful of developers. Today, there are hundreds, whose apps sell across the globe on Apple and Google Inc's Android devices. "You see these rocket ships in the industry that explode on the scene with a casual game that's easy to develop with not much money and they gain users quickly. But users get bored or angry because they can't progress without paying more money," Nexon's Mahoney told Reuters in an interview. Nexon has had some success boosting its mobile portfolio, a likely factor behind revenue growth of 24 percent in 2012 to 108 million yen ($1.1 million). LOOKING FOR ANSWERS To stand out from the crowd, developers big and small are seeking ways to build a sustainable business. EA, as one of the best-funded competitors, is turning to data analytics to keep track of its players' gaming patterns and behavior. Japanese gaming giant DeNA is experimenting with on-the-spot tweaks to its games by employees, who adjust conditions depending on what players do, CEO of DeNA West Clive Downie said. Canadian indie studio Noodlecake, known for games like "Zombie Road Trip", is employing loyalty programs similar to airlines with daily virtual currency rewards for first-time and frequent players. Others resort to tricks like seasonal deals and holiday-themed content to boost their rankings on app-download charts during the crucial holiday period. Message.Title: The supercomputer OS war is over and Linux has won decisively
Message.Msg: On top500 now... Only 3 out 500 garbage POS M$ machines left... Quote:- In the latest TOP-500 supercomputer list Linux OS family has 476 out of 500 world fastest computers. This is 95.2%. There are 3 Windows running machines (0.6%), two Azure and one HPC. The rest are various Unices (16), BSD (1) and mixed (4). The number of Linux boxes increased within the latest 6 months by seven (4 less for Unix and 3 less mixed ones). It is even better if one looks at performance share. Linux has 97.44% of the total raw GFlop power, Unix 1.77%, mixed 0.53%, Windows 0.21% and BSD 0.05%. The Linux share increased by 1.33% while all the other decreased (in the case of Windows from 0.29% to 0.21%) showing the Windows machines have on average half the power of a typical TOP-500 supercomputer. In raw power Linux boxes increased from 155 to 217 TFlop within 6 months. No other OS family increased its raw power showing that most probably the only new supercomputers build within the last 6 months were Linux ones.

Topic.Title: Microsoft Blunders Again with Mobile Office

Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting: "With Microsoft's (NASDAQ: MSFT) Windows 8 flop and the firm's restriction on gamers in its upcoming Xbox One release, it looked as if the company couldn't get more bad press. But then along came the new Microsoft Office Mobile for the iPhone. "If the company continues down its current path, it could become as obsolete as International Business Machines was in the 1990s. In the company's latest flub, Microsoft's Office Mobile doesn't follow basic file compatibility, said CloudOn's chief executive Milind Gadekar. It should be noted, however, that CloudOn is the rival to Microsoft's Office Mobile, so there is some bias in his opinion. Gadekar did admit, however, that the software is superior to CloudOn in its offline capabilities. "What the bad press means to Microsoft "Microsoft continues to shoot itself in the foot at a time when the company is trying to re-brand itself. The company has also faced criticism for the limitations it has put on users of the November release of the Xbox One. Already, the company said people can't give games away to friends more than once, and the person that receives the gift has to be a friend for at least 30 days. Furthermore, the company's Windows 8 operating system was considered user unfriendly due to confusion among users. "Having analyzed the user-unfriendliness of Microsoft's recent products and determined that the company is missing the target, you may consider selling Microsoft...." _____________________________ Google it for the rest of the discussion

Topic.Title: The supercomputer OS war is over and Linux has won decisively

Message.Msg: The supercomputer OS war is over and Linux has won decisively On top500 now... Only 3 out 500 garbage POS M$ machines left... Quote:- In the latest TOP-500 supercomputer list Linux OS family has 476 out of 500 world fastest computers. This is 95.2%. There are 3 Windows running machines (0.6%), two Azure and one HPC. The rest are various Unices (16), BSD (1) and mixed (4). The number of Linux boxes increased within the latest 6 months by seven (4 less for Unix and 3 less mixed ones). It is even better if one looks at performance share. Linux has 97.44% of the total raw GFlop power, Unix 1.77%, mixed 0.53%, Windows 0.21% and BSD 0.05%. The Linux share increased by 1.33% while all the other decreased (in the case of Windows from 0.29% to 0.21%) showing the Windows machines have on average half the power of a typical TOP-500 supercomputer. In raw power Linux boxes increased from 155 to 217 TFlop within 6 months. No other OS family increased its raw power showing that most probably the only new supercomputers build within the last 6 months were Linux ones
